The “dog days of summer” (July 3 through August 11) has nothing to do with our beloved earth-bound furry companions, but “dog” is part of the equation. According to National Geographic, the dog star named Sirius appears to rise just before the sun, in late July. The Greeks and Romans referred to these as the hottest times of the year. The Egyptians referred to Sirius as the Nile Star and when they saw it rising before dawn, they knew the Nile would flood the banks and make their ground more fertile. - Readers' Digest

Join fellow parents, educators and child development and trauma experts for an important conversation about how you can talk with young children about racial injustice and violence against Black people. Together, we’ll explore questions such as: How can parents of Black children continue to instill confidence and pride in young kids while also explaining the racial inequity and barriers that continue today? We’ll also answer questions from parents and share tips and resources you can use to continue to have these meaningful conversations now and into the future.

This live event will be recorded and available to view and share shortly after on the PBS KIDS for Parents YouTube channel.

A new era of human spaceflight is set to begin as American astronauts once again launch on an American rocket from American soil to the International Space Station as part of NASA’s Commercial Crew Program. NASA astronauts Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley will fly on SpaceX’s Crew Dragon spacecraft, lifting off on a Falcon 9 rocket at 3:22 p.m. EDT May 30, from Launch Complex 39A in Florida, for an extended stay at the space station for the Demo-2 mission.

As the final flight test for SpaceX, this mission will validate the company’s crew transportation system, including the launch pad, rocket, spacecraft, and operational capabilities. This also will be the first time NASA astronauts will test the spacecraft systems in orbit.

This is an exciting time for students and families to learn about NASA. Check out all the details at https://www.nasa.gov/

Watch the launch tomorrow at https://www.nasa.gov/nasalive

Metropolitan Lighthouse Charter School (K-10)
Bronx, NY

Our Metropolitan campus is a K–10 public charter school located in the Highbridge neighborhood of the Bronx. Growing by a grade level each year, MetLCS prides itself on having a family-centered model focused on the whole child. We take a “Responsive Classroom” approach to social development and offer a unique English as a Second Language program. Our scholars have the opportunity to develop leadership skills and forge friendships through participation in a number of sports and extracurricular activities. We recognize the important role that family plays in education and encourage participation in our annual activities, including Family Fun Day, a spelling bee, and more.

The Arts are a part of everything we do at LHA. We incorporate visual arts, music, movement, and other forms of creative expression into our program, and expose our scholars to master artists and works of art.

With such an emphasis on Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) in recent years, you may find yourself wondering why Lighthouse Academies follows an arts-infused program. Research has shown that arts infusion actually helps to better engage students. We apply core content knowledge to creative ways of learning, helping scholars better understand and retain the concepts they are learning.

Arts-infusion can also provide a different way to assess students’ critical thinking skills and their understanding of skills and concepts. We’ve seen just how successful an arts-infused program can be, as our students demonstrate the benefits of this program each day.

#HispanicHeritageMonth Spotlight:

⭐️Celebrated Mexican artist Frida Kahlo was born in Mexico City to a German immigrant father and a Mexican mother. She contracted polio when she was young which caused her to walk with a limp. In 1925, Kahlo was traveling on a bus when the vehicle collided with a streetcar. She suffered several serious injuries, including fractures in her spine and pelvis. During her recovery, she began to paint, finishing her first self-portrait the following year. Kahlo was regarded as a feminist icon for her creativity and political activism. She was the first Mexican artist to be featured in the Louvre and Mexico has declared her works national cultural heritage, prohibiting their export from the country.

Many students that attend Lighthouse Academies come from underprivileged communities where many opportunities would not otherwise be available to them. Lifetime income inequalities in our schools’ communities affect the quality of life for many of our students, resulting in an endless cycle of poverty. By providing our students with the means to achieve success personally and professionally, we aim to break this cycle and truly transform our students’ lives for the better.

The work we are doing at LHA not only affects our present students but also has the potential to impact these communities for generations to come. Upon graduating from Lighthouse Academies, many of our students have developed our same passion for improving their communities, and many even plan to return after college to make a difference. Over time, we believe that the work we do will make a lasting difference in these communities by not only inspiring students to achieve more but by providing them with the guidance to do so.

Many students that attend Lighthouse Academies come from underprivileged communities where many opportunities would not otherwise be available to them. Lifetime income inequalities in our schools’ communities affect the quality of life for many of our students, resulting in an endless cycle of poverty. By providing our students with the means to achieve success personally and professionally, we aim to break this cycle and truly transform our students’ lives for the better.

The work we are doing at LHA not only affects our present students, but also has the potential to impact these communities for generations to come. Upon graduating from Lighthouse Academies, many of our students have developed our same passion for improving their communities, and many even plan to return after college to make a difference. Over time, we believe that the work we do will make a lasting difference in these communities by not only inspiring students to achieve more, but by providing them with the guidance to do so.

Learn more about our impact here.
